comments.commentBody:
"As the city's chief executive he should be proposing an answer"
There is an appealing logic to what you write, but should the office of mayor be vacant until someone with "the answer" comes along?
Let them (CWA) walk and replace everyone of them, same same Reagan did with Air Traffuc Controllers.

What the article misses with the comment of the "wireline side of the business declining" is the fact that Truro the visible side of it is declining, the hidden side that most people do not see is building more and more. Every cell tower getting faster 4g needs fiber to get it to the tower, all the companies Web Access and ip phones and the free WiFi all go on fibers that the equipment is still kept in a "wireline" Central office. It's a cloud to the public but the backbone of the Internet still travels through the wireline side. So Plain Old Telephone  (POTS) may be dying but the new equipment still needs to be repaired and wired or should I say Fibered......
Wait until it rains.
Oddly enough, with 40,000 on strike, there is no drop in quality of Verizon service.

does anyone remember Iridium?  Now there was a market plan.  What is system being used for now? I'll give a change to find out.  6 billion dollars wasted in 9 months, bought on open market for 35million. Go Bernie

Is there no one who remembers the time when unions were the good guys?
Then we were told that companies were relocating to the south because of the lower prices of labor.
The we were told that jobs were being lost because of competition from foreign companies. All this because of those damnable unions. So the average bloke who was not a member of the union bought the corporation's line and turned anti-union. And it never occurred to them that they were being scammed by the corporations.
Unions used to be welcome into the community because they represented good paying jobs and benefits. Non-union companies scurried to be competitive with their pay packages.
Now, when a union worker has a pay or benefit better than non-union workers, the first impulse is to side with the corporation. Soon, if people continue trying to destroy worker representation, we will all pay the price.
Ask a non-union worker, Who represents you when you have been screwed over by your company?
There really is class warfare in America, it's the lower middle class vs the middle class and it's being sponsored by politicians and corporations.

It's time we take our country back from psychopath CEOs who have increased their compensation from 30 times the average worker to 300 times the average worker.

Stop corporate greed!

Strike!
Verizon overcharges and I am sure the money never reaches the workers.

This article completely lacks specific issues; therefore, how is the reader to know the merits of the argument?  NT should also behave in the manner of responsible corporate citizen and fulfill the duty to inform.

Wrong Matt, when 40,000 workers get paid fairly, the economy thrives. These are the people who spend money in your neighborhood, not the top execs who live in gated communities.

Verizon has competion and that will always keep costs down. Margins for the company might shrink but unless your a stock holder, who gets a very handsome dividend by the way, you shouldnt really care.

Mal Adapted (kudos on the name & pic) having access to electricity generated from natural gas would allow conservation of water when water supplies are limited. Add solar or wind and Zambia could have power and be better able to manage their generating resources and water supply.

It may not be a perfect solution but it's a way forward that minimizes harm.
Check your facts. This dam has been a huge success being the back bone of a relativly reliable power supply for decades.

The vast majority of Zambia's woes are related to commodity price declines as unrelated to climate change as is the drought. Appending climate change to their problems is literally conflating a tertiary matter to causation.
We'll keep waiting. Meanwhile highly educated people build close to the coast and enjoy the shoreline.

In order to attribute any short term climate event, such as a drought, to human-caused temperature increases at a particular location one would need sufficient regional precipitation data to understand precipitation cycles over a long term and a regional precipitation model capable of correctly forecasting the current drought and clearly showing the difference between the weather pattern that would have existed had CO2 been at a lower level and the observed weather pattern existing because of a higher level of CO2. If that is happening here, the author has forgotten to inform us that this is the case. The assertion in the headline that climate change is the driver of the current drought and economic downturn has no basis and no educated person should give serious thought to what is asserted here.

This obsession with CO2 needs to be seriously tempered. Having the lights on and food to eat is more important that obsessing about every gram of carbon in the atmosphere. If your belly is full; it's easy to be an environmentalist. If you're looking to survive; not so much. In the words of a liberal, check your privilege.

Greg Gerner:  Don't you know the CEO of UnitedHealth earned every penny of that $66 million by performing lab tests at $12/hour?  Very rich people are well known to be more honest than the hoi polloi -- they say so themselves.
Hillary didn't just misspeak. This was a deliberate twisting of the facts for political gain, which in its own small way shows why her dishonesty and unfavorable ratings are so high.
She didn't misspeak. She twisted the facts in a really stupid way.
Hillary didn't just misspeak. This was a deliberate twisting of the facts for political gain, which in its own small way shows why her dishonesty and unfavorable ratings are so high.
Not to worry, folks. If Hillary misspeaks, the media will out her, pronto. I'm surprised this bit didn't make the front page of the Times.

In 20 years, it just might work -- with plenty of modifications. That's four computer generations. Nanotechnology will be much further advanced.

However, the planning seems all based on what we can do today, including the cost. In the meantime, some billionaires are concerned about climate change. Others try to rig elections. Would be great if we could get the latter to put their bucks into this boondoggle.

One-gram objects will not have the power to send us signals even if we grant that they will be able to record images and even study planets -- difficult when passing a star at 0.2c. Enough power to send that signal would explode that small probe. The plan seems to be to send so many of these probes that aiming them won't be an issue, but it will.

I love the ambition but not the practical aspects. Instead of Mars One, we have Centauri One.

Let's work on Mars and our solar system a bit more. Someone has been reading to many science fiction stories. I'll stick to Mars Rhapsody.
DG, don't you know the Minister of Health is a free-market ideologue like all the other Conservative ministers?

Google search yields one human DNA molecule weighs about 3.6 * 10**-12 grams, so allocating about one-fortieth of a one-gram probe's weight we could put one DNA molecule from everyone currently on the planet on each probe.

Engrave assembly instructions on the package, and we can all go to Alpha Centauri. Charge us each $1.25 and we will have raised the funds for the trip.

This is the kind of outlook that will prevent us from achieving sustainable living. Without far reaching scientific achievements we will not be able to gain enough knowledge to develop a sustainable society. This is not an attempt to jump ship but to understand the space we live in. It is just as important as any other scientific pursuit, the ability to understand will help us thrive.
Yes, I think so.

What a dim view you have on reality. You've watched too many Star Wars movies. I repeat....we are NOT going to Mars. Why would anyone want to go there in the first place? Platitudes such as your response is indicative of my point exactly. You'd be better off thinking of ways to escape NYC when the next climate-change induced super storm renders your city uninhabitable.

@Clyde Feelings,
Aw, c'mon. That's kinda mean don'tcha think?

4-14-16@12:55 am
Nice idea, but probably a little silly, considering the expense, but it gives that distinguished group of old gents like Dyson something to do.
